FUNCTION BASE64 :
PT_SIZE
encodes 8 bit binary data into ASCII data
A text block (string, binary, array of bytes) will be base64 encoded. The maximum of the block is set in the
TextBlockSize
parameter.
This size can be changed but must be divisible by 3.
If the text block is only a part of a text and followed by more text, the size must be
TextBlockSize.iBlockSize
and
the
isLastBlock
variable must be set to
FALSE
. If a text is not followed by another block, the specific length
of it must be used and
isLastBlock
has to be set to
TRUE
, as shown in the following example. The reason is
three 8-bit letters will become four 6-bit letters. If only two 8-Bit letters are remaining at the end, the encoded text is
filled with â=â. This must only be at the end of a text.
Example:
StringToConvert
:
PT_SIZE
;
EncodedString
:
PT_SIZE
;
byError
:
BYTE
;
sText
:
STRING
:=
'This is a test string.'
;
StringToConvert.uiSize
:=
LEN
(
sText
);
(* When another block follows, use the size TextBlockSize.iBlockSize
and set isLastBlock to FALSE. *)
StringToConvert.pString
:=
ADR
(
sText
);
EncodedString
:=
Base64
(
TextToEncode
:=
StringToConvert
,
isLastBlock
:=
TRUE
,
pbyError
:=
ADR
(
byError
));
